Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with backboned animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding a huge portion of the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. This project, the Echinoderm Tree of Life Project, will resolve the phylogenetic placement of Echinoderms within the tree of life and clarify important unresolved relationships among major echinoderm lineages using data from genetic sequencing and anatomy.

Echinoderms are fascinating, and their unique features, such as mutable ligaments and novel means of detecting light, have biomedical engineering applications. Because research on such marine animals and their adaptations is naturally attractive to young people, excellent students are expected to be recruited and the importance of science will be communicated to a broad audience. Long-term impacts, embodied by scientific publications, textbooks, anatomical and genomic data, and extensive pages in the Tree of Life and Encyclopedia of Life web projects, will provide resources to researchers and educators. Outreach will include videos and broadcasts about marine exploration and applications of fundamental biological research across the biomedical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary student trained on this project: was Allison Miller, who received her B.Sc. from UC San Diego and is pursuing a phylogenetic study of the Holothuroidea. Allison has done fieldwork on Guam, Chuuk and Kosrae in Micronesia.  She presented a poster at the 12th International Coral Reef Symposium.  She continues microscope work photographing ossicles of potential exemplar species.  She has learned much about the systematics and morphology of her group, as well as phylogenetic theory and methods. Researchers at the Korea Ocean Research and Development Institution, Dr. Heung Sik Park and Mr. Sun Wook Kim, M.Sc., were collaborating with field work at their research station in Chuuk, Micronesia, to provide material for our project. During the course of collections, we found substantial extensions of geographic range for little known and undescribed species.I was also training two other graduate students in systematics and evolution; both are a members of underrepresented minorities, and all three are women. Substantial collections of echinoderms, as well as other invertebrates were generated by our collecting efforts funded by the grant. We made these collections widely available to interested researchers by depositing them at the Florida Museum of Natural History. Collections data are at: http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/databases/mala/intro.htm. Species presence/absence data during collecting trips has been provided to local government authorities via unpublished reports to assist in producing management plans aimed at the conservation of coral-reef natural resources.
